column1: #Text=Do you think a political solution is the only realistic means to resolve the Syrian issue ?
#Text=: At the moment , both sides [ in Syria ] evidently feel they can still obtain their objectives through force .
#Text=Perhaps one of them will be proved right ; or , perhaps there will be a long-term stalemate with Syria split between regime and opposition forces .
#Text=One important change is the chemical weapons agreement ; which now makes it much more difficult for the US or Israel to intervene militarily .
#Text=The deal also gives the regime some degree of status as a legal authority with which outside powers must negotiate .

#Text=That weakens the hand of the opposition ; but , it could open a door for an international diplomatic intervention to achieve — firstly — a cease fire . and perhaps then something more substantive .
#Text=: There is no appetite for the kinds of expensive and very hard interventions [ undertaken ] in Iraq and Afghanistan .
#Text=And , in any case , the US and its allies do n't have the money to fund this , and their publics evidently feel no case has been made yet for getting involved .
#Text=People are weary of the endless arguments in the Middle-East , and feel that they should now be left to deal with their own issues .
#Text=China , in particular , has tried to maintain as strong a [ ... ] network of benign support in the region as possible , while avoiding getting sucked into problems .
#Text=There is no viable opposition in Syria that would make it easier to justify intervention ; and , no easy way of seeing how this tragic civil war is going to be easily ended .

#Text=: Syria has become the arena for a proxy war among regional and extra-regional players and yes its civil war will not end until all key players and their external supporters develop a political will to end the conflict .
#Text=For the conflict to end , the bankers feeding the conflict should agree to stop funding it .
#Text=But , it will depend on Russia , China , and the US , being able to come up with a compromise solution .
#Text=That looks [ to be ] a long way off .
#Text=For many years , Syria has been considered Iran 's " closest ally " .
#Text=What vested interest does the Iranian government have in keeping Bashar al-Assad in power ?

#Text=: These interests are primarily strategic , with both countries sharing common interests in relation to Lebanon — particularly the Hezbollah group — and [ as ] deterrence against Israel [ i intervention ] .
#Text=: Iran 's interests align very closely with that of Russia in supporting Syria and opposing the United States .
#Text=Further , during this last week , President Putin offered to help Iran build a second nuclear reactor .

#Text=The policies of Russia , Iran , and Syria align quite closely ; thus leading some — such as myself — to argue that we are seeing the rise of an " authoritarian axis " of states , whose policies are coordinated .
#Text=: First , Syria was Iran 's only ally against Saddam Hussein and [ an ] indispensable partner in Lebanon since the early 1980s .
